name: TheAtlantic
text: Over the course of the coronavirus crisis, @khushbuoshea’s relatives have sent her homeopathic “cures,” astrological charts predicting the end of the pandemic, and conspiracy theories. She writes about why misinformation spreads in families: https://t.co/mrFTentgZd

name: TheAtlantic
text: iPads wrapped in plastic bags. Zoom goodbyes. The coronavirus made caring for the sickest patients “an entirely new universe,” @sarahzhang reports. https://t.co/SALiOOQBij

name: TheAtlantic
text: Understanding the present moment requires grappling with a history stained by racial inequity. We compiled a list of writing on race and racism spanning @TheAtlantic's 163-year history: https://t.co/UdUDRh9hPc

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: Supplements and vitamins claim to “boost your immune system.” @JamesHamblin explains why this is nonsense. https://t.co/JtL3Rnm9g3

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @prashantrao: If you want to understand what went wrong in Hong Kong, @TMclaughlin3's profile of Carrie Lam contains incredible detail, color, and depth, based on dozens of interviews and months of reporting.

And yet, as he notes, she is not the problem: https://t.co/zUroCVNuQD

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: "When we ignore the dialectical relation between the labels “black” and “white,” we treat a bloodstained product of history as a neutral, objective fact about the world,” writes @KAnthonyAppiah https://t.co/LvYa6JkxLA

name: TheAtlantic
text: The former national security adviser's much-awaited, and controversially timed, tell-all appears to paint a president at his worst. From @mimbsy: https://t.co/m04L0XbE67

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @denisewills: This story is incredible. https://t.co/9HN9SHnxQx

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: Carrie Lam has been a unique failure as Hong Kong's leader. Yet she is merely the symptom of its ills, @TMclaughlin3 writes, in this deeply-reported and thoughtful profile, which delves into both the person, and the system, that has doomed Hong Kong: https://t.co/zUroCVvTZ5

name: TheAtlantic
text: "How do the human beings whom communities hire, train, and supervise," @R_T_Rybak writes, "end up killing people they are supposed to protect and serve?" https://t.co/Nn6sEXIwM9

name: TheAtlantic
text: Carrie Lam has been a unique failure as Hong Kong's leader. Yet she is merely a symptom of the city's ills, @TMclaughlin3 writes: https://t.co/0usfF3MFmB

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @russellberman: In Arizona and Texas, mayors and county leaders are confronting a resurgence of coronavirus cases with their hands tied by Republican governors https://t.co/9rqbgiMIRi

name: TheAtlantic
text: In this week’s “How to Build a Life,” @arthurbrooks explains how embracing negative feelings leads to emotional strength, which in turn leads to a good, meaningful life: https://t.co/BRclvsqOuC

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @julieebeck: in this week’s How to Build a Life, @arthurbrooks argues that negative emotions are a necessary part of a good life—and gives strategies for coexisting with them peacefully
https://t.co/seU8Qnq9Ly

name: TheAtlantic
text: If HBO’s Roy Cohn documentary “Bully. Coward. Victim.” tends to dart around its subject, it’s nonetheless a fascinating addition to the canon for those who seek to understand Trump, writes @sophieGG: https://t.co/mpQOqzR3Mo

name: TheAtlantic
text:
The Supreme Court upheld the DACA program for young, undocumented immigrants, in a ruling against the Trump administration.

In November 2019, Garrett Epps wrote about the dangers of rescinding the program for the nearly 700,000 people who rely on it. https://t.co/Z7db4nP1MH

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdamSerwer: I interviewed @SmithsonianSec and former @NMAAHC founding director Lonnie Bunch about the history of black protest against police brutality, and what to expect going forward https://t.co/VTWEDdLZpU

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @thomaswright08: In which I dissent on the prevailing criticism of John Bolton. He is actually doing the right thing while others remain silent. https://t.co/8o3d092vba

name: TheAtlantic
text: If HBO’s Roy Cohn documentary, “Bully. Coward. Victim.,” tends to dart around its subject, it’s nonetheless a fascinating addition to the canon for those who seek to understand Trump, writes @sophieGG: https://t.co/ZJCMguPIYf

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: I will forever be haunted by this story. Just astonishing, and heartbreaking: https://t.co/tuDpioJw3i

name: TheAtlantic
text: I’m no fan of his, but he is doing a service to the nation by speaking out, @thomaswright08 writes: https://t.co/lEqZlPjpxY

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @prashantrao: An utterly fascinating piece on Hong Kong by the essential @TMcLaughlin3: https://t.co/zUroCVvTZ5

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @RonBrownstein: The watershed moments of 60s protest can seem in retrospect like towering peaks of transformative activism far beyond any contemporary experience. But history may look back on this period as a comparable transition in U.S. politics & culture. Here's why  https://t.co/vXnN9ctqVF

name: TheAtlantic
text: "A good reason to capitalize the racial designation 'black,' then, is precisely that black, in this sense, isn’t a natural category, but a social one—a collective identity—with a particular history," @KAnthonyAppiah writes: https://t.co/SbfbBjYPd8

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I think people said, 'I’m tired of mourning. Let me do something besides mourn. Let me challenge a country to live up to its stated ideals.'" @SmithsonianSec Lonnie Bunch spoke with @AdamSerwer about this moment in the long arc of history: https://t.co/ah9YJ16Mgu

name: TheAtlantic
text: A collection of images of some of the hundreds of bird species that call Turkey’s Lake Van home. Via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/qBdUWziBF0

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @DKThomp: Columbia sociologist Todd Gitlin’s description of the 1960s protests, in a piece comparing to 2020:

“A great political defeat and a great cultural success ... We ended up with the left marching on the English Department while the right took Washington.”

https://t.co/mmzbIj0mnh

name: TheAtlantic
text: Watch live: Join staff writers @FranklinFoer and @McKayCoppins for a live conversation about how Russia’s interference in the 2016 election is only a prelude of what’s to come in 2020. https://t.co/m827btYXlq

name: TheAtlantic
text:
“I’m not a person who can be intimate,” says Izidor Ruckel.

Izidor is one of the tens of thousands of abandoned children raised in Romania’s “child gulags.” @MelissaFGreene reports on what’s become of them as adults. https://t.co/2uUMbBul9e

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @nora_kelly: An exquisite piece by Vann Newkirk, written after the Philando Castile verdict in Minneapolis three years ago: https://t.co/9QPLS2aCYL

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Has something snapped for good in Roberts? Has he reached some legal or political breaking point?" @davidfrum writes: https://t.co/G80Szo0RXH

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @arthurbrooks: To get stronger from suffering, we can all learn from athletes, monks, the elderly, and @StephenAtHome Colbert. My column today @TheAtlantic.
https://t.co/PgujQsKNcy

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Having asked for more authority over the pandemic, local officials are now stuck with it at the worst possible time," writes @GrahamDavidA: https://t.co/yXEuUZPxtl

name: TheAtlantic
text: In 1990, the world discovered Romania’s network of “child gulags,” in which an estimated 170,000 abandoned infants, children, and teens were being raised, @MelissaFGreene writes. Here’s what’s become of them. https://t.co/bDsq5yEBj3

name: TheAtlantic
text: History will perhaps judge Carrie Lam as the leader who killed her city without needing any tanks, @TMclaughlin3 writes of Hong Kong's chief executive. https://t.co/mJUHRKGW8Q
